name: Led Zeppelin in Other Words Quiz | Led Zeppelin | 10 Questions

questions.text: Drinking a hot beverage on your own. (3,3,3)
questions.explanation:
Tea For One.

	"Tea For One" is a track on the 1976 album "Presence", and at 9 minutes 27 seconds is one of the longest songs recorded by Led Zeppelin.

Tangerine.

	"Tangerine" appears on the 1970 album "Led Zeppelin III". The song is based on the Yardbirds number "Knowing That I'm Losing You".

Fool In The Rain.

	"Fool In The Rain" is a track on the 1979 album "In Through The Out Door", and was influenced by the soccer world cup held in Argentina in 1978.

Moby Dick.

	"Moby Dick" is an instrumental track on the 1969 album "Led Zeppelin II". It featured regularly in Led Zeppelin's concerts, as a vehicle for a John Bonham drum solo.

questions.text: Heading for a west coast U.S. State.  (5,2,10)
questions.explanation:
Going To California.

	"Going To California" is a track on the untitled album generally referred to as "Led Zeppelin IV". Apparently, the song is about Joni Mitchell.

Night Flight.

	"Night Flight" is a track on the 1975 album "Physical Graffiti". The song is about a man trying to avoid being drafted into the army.

Hot Dog.

	Appearing on the 1979 album "In Through The Out Door", "Hot Dog" is a Rockabilly type of tune about a girl from Texas.

questions.text: A tune about someone who has moved to another country to live. (9,4)
questions.explanation:
Immigrant Song.

	"Immigrant Song" is the opening track on the 1970 album "Led Zeppelin III". The song was released as a single in the USA, reaching number 16 on the Billboard chart. In the early 1970s, the song was a traditional set-opener at Led Zeppelin gigs.

Black Dog.

	"Black Dog" is the opening track on Led Zeppelin's untitled fourth album, released in 1971. The lyrics of the song have nothing to do with a dog at all, the title coming from a Labrador Retriever which wandered in and out of the studio during the recording of the album.

The Song Remains The Same.

	"The Song Remains The Same" is the opening track on the 1973 album "Houses of the Holy". Originally intended to be an instrumental track, the title of this song was also used for a live album and film released by Led Zeppelin in 1976.
